review: Streaming from my tablet and computer have been incredibly easy.  Once the device is plugged in, you use a supported app and can send it from your tablet to the chromecast through your wifi connection.  The picture is clear and in HD.A few warnings- if your wifi connection is slow and you normally have lags in viewing films on your tablet/pc, you will have the same lags in the chromecast.  It's not the fault of your chromecast, it's your wifi.  Second- It does use your battery a bit to watch/stream the video, so plug in while you are streaming.

review: If you are looking for a device to stream anything to your TV, this is not what you are looking for.What this device does is allow Chromecast enabled sites / apps to stream direct to your Chromecast, freeing up your laptop / mobile device.  So if you are watching (say) a Netflix show on your tablet, and click the new little Chromecast icon, the stream will switch over to your Chromecast, and you can get on with other stuff on your tablet.At the moment, sites supporting Chromecast are limited.  But they do include YouTube, Netflix, Hulu Plus, Plex, and a few others.  And there should be a lot more appearing soon.So if you watch a lot of Netflix, or Hulu Plus, or Youtube ... this is $35 well spent.  Just understand what you are getting before you buy this, so you won't be disappointed.  And no, it doesn't support Amazon Prime!One other issue to note is HDMI switching.  Even if your TV supports HDMI CEC, the "standard" that allows for automatic switching between HDMI inputs, you will still end up needing to manually switch inputs using your TV remote.  The best you can achieve for automatic switching is for the input to switch to either the TV or the Chromecast when one of them powers up or down.  You can't have it automatically switch from TV to Chromecast when you watch a Chromecast stream, then back when the stream is finished.  This isn't a Chromecast issue, this is just the nature of HDMI switching.  Maybe one day the industry will sort all that out!
